values:
So, the dinner was cooked and the guests arrived. The boys were stuffed into their costumes and we snapped a few shots before departing. The night was cool but not cold. We started early and hoped to be back before 9 PM. My biggest concern was stupid drivers and older kids setting the wrong example. The boys were excited and I was placed in charge of navigation so that we were guaranteed not to get lost...in our own neighborhood.

M chose not to wear a costume. Even though she was still playing the idea of me lending her one of mine. I wasn't interested in listening to her moan that the damned thing didn't fit all night, so I said not to worry about it. It wasn't about us being in costume, it was about the boys having fun. I then ignored anything else she had to say on the matter and worked on my kidlet's eye makeup. She took the hint. YAY!

Her 'demon' was a red Power Ranger. He decided that he wanted his hair to be dyed red as well. So, she spent the final few minutes we had coming red goop into his hair with a doll sized comb. I think she does this stuff just to annoy the crap out of me.

I like planning and scheduling things. If you stick to the plan everything moves smoothly and seamlessly along. For some reason, despite having all the time in the world for preparation, she waits until the last minute to do everything all at once. I asked her to leave a little bit early from work, if she could, so we could get dinner into the boys before trekking up and down the hills behind my apartment. She leaves an hour and a half early, to get her emissions test done (it has to be done by the end of October, funny she's had the paperwork this entire freaking month and NOW she has to do it or lose the ability to drive her car!) and then to come back all the way across town, even further than she was when she was at work, pick up her demon and then get to my place.

I told her to call me when she got out of work. I had to call her. She tells me about the emissions testing. I tell her to call me after she's done with that so we can figure out when I should get dinner actually started in the oven. I have to call her again, she's on her way to pick up A. I tell her what we are having for dinner and that I need to know how far away she is so I know when to put the chicken in the oven. She tells me she's only 20 minutes or so away and to go ahead. I do, but not until she informs me that while my dinner of homemade mashed potatoes, garden salad and homemade chicken nuggets sounds great, A probably won't eat half of it because he doesn't like THAT stuff and will only eat McD's nuggets. He would devour my potatoes though, if given the chance. I said, we'll see. 35 minutes later, the food is on the table and I'm about to tell my monkey to dig in when they come walking through the door. Go wash your hands and sit down, we have to keep moving.

Another half hour later, she's still talking and I'm clearing the table. I hate to be rude like that but we have a schedule to keep. She wants to talk about her latest medical development. She's having headaches and dizzy spells. Sounds awful. Are you done with that? Her doctor wants to run tests. Oh, well, that would be useful so you can at least KNOW what it is that is bothering you. Guessing never really cured anyone of anything you know. Is A supposed to be taking his shoes and costume off?

She tends to him, she starts unpacking his treat bucket, the back-up bag and then starts to tell me about her flashlight. Apparently, she forgot to remove the batteries that were in it and they exploded or something. Don't worry we're covered. I bought glowsticks for the boys, I have a blinking 'stop' light and a flashlight for the sidewalk. I mentioned I like to plan for just about everything, right? I also have a package of makeup remover cloths in case B's eye makeup starts to run and needs to be removed. He's got a vinyl mask this year, and I distinctly remember the difficulty breathing, the sweating and the bad peripheral vision those things come with.

She takes out A's mask and I wonder where she's been storing it. Now we are regaled with an additional 5 minutes of M cussing at a cheap plastic mask that has dents in it. Then she removed the hair dye and comb and tortures her son for another 15 minutes. My kid is dressed, made up and ready to bolt out the door. It is 6:30 PM, this is exactly where we are supposed to be according to my schedule. I'm trying not to be seriously annoyed. Really I am.

She wants me to check A's hair for any missed spots. Seriously? The sun is setting, do you think people will inspect him at each house he stops at? Are we concerned that missing a tiny piece that only you can see is going to upset HIM? Ass out door, or drive home. I smiled, so I wasn't being completely mean. Right?

We're outside, we have to visit A's grandmother and her girlfriend first. Because I like to get the unpleasantness out of the way. The awkwardness they create could fill a stadium. They like me, I can't stand them (I have no tolerance for alcoholics who aren't willing to get help and wonder why the world hates them or whatever it is they moan about) and M thinks that I should give them the benefit of the doubt. The only reason M isn't one of them is because I tortured her enough to convince her she needed help. I'm the best friend to have around when you are doing stupid things with an addiction. I'm the person who would probably od your ass and then ride with you to the hospital so I could be there when you wake up and smack the crap out of you. Of course, that could explain why my friends love me so much. I'm evil and it works for me. ~shrug~

Anywho, we get out of the crazy, awkward place and start the real fun. My kidlet is practically running everywhere and we have to constantly remind them to remember their manners and to actually say Trick or Treat. The excitement is driving them insane and of course it is testing M's patience and making me laugh. I'm the sidewalk spotter, which means I'm too big to squeeze around most people's tiny driveways to walk up to the houses with the boys. I stand on the sidewalk with my blinking light and give the boys a point of return, M goes up with the boys when it isn't crowded with kids. B actually scared a few people because of his costume. He broke in a toddler who was out for his first Halloween experience. Daddy had to rescue him. I tried not to laugh too hard.

Eventually, we were getting tired. We stopped for a few minutes of rest and to let B breathe fresh air. A took his mask off at some point and was trick or treating with his lovely red hair aflame. B kept taking his mask off to let the air touch his face and then he'd slide it on when we came to a house. We emptied the treat buckets twice that night and by 8:30 PM we were headed back to my apartment to warm up and wind down. M and A relaxed for a second. There was a brief argument about when A was going to eat his candy and then they packed up and left. I unwrapped my werewolf and let him take his glow sticks into his room to play for a bit before bedtime. The last dregs of his energy enraptured with glowing green lines and swirls he created with the sticks. 9 PM, me and the TV, monkey in bed, cats curled  up next to me on the sofa and suddenly I realized...NaNoWriMo starts tomorrow.

@#%$!^!#!&$@!

I need sleep.

Here are the pics:

With the Wiccan New Year approaching this Friday, I've been working on starting this Samhain off a little better. I've pulled everything out of the front closet and sorted through it all. By the end of the day yesterday, we had 5 large garbage bags, 1 pet gate, 1 child's playpen, and 4 small boxes stored in my car for Goodwill. We had 2 large garbage bags and 2 medium sized boxes heading to the garbage.

Today, I've cleared a drawer o'crap and finished filling a large garbage bag. I've pulled everything out of my son's closet that I'd been storing in there. I've already got 2 large garbage bags for Goodwill and 1 large garbage bag with actual garbage. I've got a few more boxes to go but I can get that done in a half hour or so.

I've been feeling very rushed and stressed lately. I've mentioned before that the more stressed I feel the more I have to organize things. I've got to find a job, eventually this place is going to look very Japanese, you know very minimalist, if I keep throwing out stuff.

So I took a break. I decided to have some fun and have some quality kidlet time. I present:

Pumpkin Carving

A perfectly lovely pumpkin. Let's cut it's head off!

YAY!! Now let's remove it's guts and various other innards.

Excellent! Now...let's make a pretty design or something in it's flesh.

Yes, cut my little assistant. Cut! Cut! CUT!

Hmmm, interesting pattern. Let us test this work of yours.

 

BRILLIANT!

Well, I am back from a frustrating week with stupid people. I have returned for a much needed posting of love and baking. Behold, Rho's Vanishing Oatmeal Raisin Cookie Recipe!

Step 1: Gather all needed ingredients.

1 cup (2 sticks) margarine, softened

1 cup firmly packed brown sugar

1/2 cup granulated sugar

2 eggs

1 teasponn vanilla

1 1/2 cups flour

1 teaspoon baking soda

1 teaspoon cinnamon

1/2 teaspoon salt

3 cups old fashined oats

1 cup raisins

Step 2: Beat together margarine and sugars until creamy.

Step 3: Beat together eggs and vanilla until well blended.

Step 4: Add eggs and vanilla mixture to sugar mixture. Mix well.

Step 5: Add flour, baking soda, cinnamon and salt.

Step 6: Stir in oats, be sure to mix between each cup to keep clumps from forming.

Step 7: Once all cups are added, the mixture should be moist.

Step 8: Add raisins.

Step 9: Mix thorougly and completely.

Step 10: Drop by tablespoonfuls onto ungreased cookie sheet, I use non-stick aluminum foil to cut down on the mess.

Step 11: Place in oven at 350 degrees F for 10 to 12 minutes or until golden brown.

Enjoy!

Note: I usually make a baker's dozen to have a full dozen and one cookie to cool and taste test. This allows me to keep a good eye on the recipe without having to torture unsuspecting guinea pigs. Though, it is fun to see their faces light up when you get it right.

I was recently given the challenge to find a no yeast recipe for cinnamon rolls that wouldn't taste like cardboard. I love a challenge. Let's dance.

Step 1: Gather ingredients.

2 cups all purpose flour

2 tablespoons white sugar

4 teaspoons baking powder

1 teaspoon salt

¼ cup butter, chilled

1 cup cold milk

1/3 cup butter or margarine, softened

1 cup packed brown sugar

3 teaspoons ground cinnamon

1/3 cup raisins - optional

½ cup confectioner's sugar

¼ cup milk

¼ cup water

 

Step 2: Cream the 1/3 cup butter or margarine, brown sugar and cinnamon together.

 

Step 3: Drop 1 teaspoon into each of 12 greased muffin tins. Save the remaining mixture.

 

Step 4: In a large bowl, combine flour, sugar, baking powder, and salt.

 

Step 5: Cut ¼ cup butter into mixture until crumbly. Make a well in center, and pour in milk.

 

Step 6: Stir to form a soft dough, adding a bit more milk if needed.

 

Step 7: Turn dough out on lightly floured surface.

 

Step 8: Knead 8 to 10 times.

 

Step 9: Roll into a rectangle about 1/3 inch thick and 12 inches long.

 

Step 10: Spread the remaining cinnamon mixture over dough rectangle.

 

Step 11: Sprinkle the raisins over top. Remember this is optional. If you don’t want raisins go to Step 12.

 

Step 12: Roll up as for Jelly roll.

 

Step 13: Mark the roll to be sure you have 12 rolls when you are done.

 

Step 14: Cut into 12 slices. Place cut side down in muffin pan.

 

Step 15: Preheat oven to 400 degrees. Once preheated, slide the rolls in for 20 to 25 minutes.

 

Step 16: Once rolls are in, you can now prep the glaze. Take confectioners sugar, ¼ cup water and ¼ cup milk and combine in small bowl.

 

Mix thoroughly and to thicken place in freezer or fridge, for 15 to 20 minutes.

Turn rolls out on a cooling tray/rack, drizzle glaze over cinnamon rolls. Enjoy.

Now don’t get me wrong, I love my little brother. I just don’t see the point of calling me because he’s bored. I’m bored too, dammit! I don’t call other people to wallow in it with them. I’m happy to hear from him and all, but I honestly wonder if he could just perhaps have a topic to talk about…perhaps something he would like to actually discuss?
 
So far, he’s rambled on about his car and what he wants to do to it. Unfortunately, I’m not a car person and half of what he said just wafted out of the other ear. He’s talked about his schedule, which still sounds pretty cool to me. He goes to school, goes to work and goes home to sleep or play video games. He doesn’t do much in the way of chores, he doesn’t have many things to do and he has friends that come and see him all the time. What the hell is he complaining about?!
 
Yesterday he decided to talk about gaming systems. He talked about the game he’s currently working through and then he asked me if I’ve heard of it. Then he went a little stunned as I explained that I hadn’t. He asked me what kind of gaming system I had. The conversation went something like this:
 
Him: Do you have a PS2?
Me: No.
H: A playstation?
M: Nope.
H: ~slightly squeaky~ Xbox?
M: Nope.
H: What you guys DO?
M: Well, we have computers, books, we got to the park or walk around somewhere and we have books.
H: What is wrong with you?
 
I laughed for a bit and explained that I wasn’t comfortable with today’s source of entertainment, mainly because of its level of violence and lack of solid moral guidelines. Of course, he goes on to tell me that the games aren’t that violent and if ‘there’s a strong family to teach the kid the difference between reality and fiction, there shouldn’t be a problem.’
 
~sigh~ So once again, I haven’t been heard. The kidlet has Aspberger’s. This means that one of the symptoms, as such as there are noticeable symptoms for this kind of disorder, is that he is incapable of separating fiction and reality some of the time. Nothing I do is going to completely protect my son from his own wandering mind. I can only limit his access to things that potentially could lead to further lapses in cognitive awareness. Hence, no violent or morally vacuous games in the home. He has learning games and standard hand-eye coordination games and strategic building games.

Here is the kidlet and his very happy making Cello. Enjoy.
 
 
 
  

 
Hire Me via PayPerPost Direct!

Rho’s Homemade Banana Bread
 
Step 1: Get ripe bananas, two or three usually work.
 
 
Now, mash them up. I like to leave some chunky bits in there, a sort of gooey taste of banana surprise in the bread.
 
Step 2: Melt some butter. 1/3 cup is the bare minimum for us fatty conscious peeps.
 
 
Mix with mashed bananas. The smell is starting to work on you, isn’t it?
 
Step 3: Get your sugar, egg and vanilla ready. 1 cup of sugar (it can be reduced to ¾ cup if need be), 1 egg (beaten), and 1 tsp of vanilla.
 
 
Here’s the beaten egg.
 
 
There’s the vanilla, sugar and egg learning how to hang with the butter and mashed bananas. The smell should be making your stomach growl, right about now.
 
Step 4: Now let’s sprinkle some salt in there and some baking soda. Just a little bit, 1 tsp baking soda and a pinch of salt should do it.
 
 
Step 5: We’re going to add the flour in last, sparingly. We want the bananas to cling to the flour and the batter to thicken but not clump. So in this step, we’re going to preheat the oven to 350 degrees and grease a loaf pan.
 
 
Step 6: Start adding the flour to the mix, slowly now, we don’t want lumpy dough, we want creamy mildly thick batter. I add ½ cup and stir it completely, and ½ cup and so on. Since your working with 1 ½ cups of flour, you’ve got time to do it right.
 
 
Step 7: Now, we pour that smooth and creamy bad boy right into that greased pan. Your oven should be preheated by now, so slide the puppy in and walk away for an hour. You heard me, an hour. Banana bread is shy; it doesn’t need you looking over its shoulder all the time.
 
 
There, now after it is done. You’ll want to cool it on a rack for a bit, and then slide it out of the loaf pan to cool completely. You can THEN eat it, or wrap it up and store in the fridge or cool, dry place of your choice.
 
See? Now don’t say I didn’t teach you anything.

Went in for my follow up appt. and had a new set of labs done. They forgot to check my cholesterol but they did check my white blood cell count and thyroid. My thyroid is fine but my WBC is up again. I have to see a hematologist. So great, more crap to deal with. Now I have to go back and pick up my referral and give more blood to check my cholesterol levels. I did start all of this with the hopes of getting healthier after all. I just didn’t realize how screwed I was in the first place.

 

Of course, my ‘support team’ is waiting for the news of my imminent death timeline or to hear I’ve got cancer or something. So much for the happy go lucky people in my life.

 

Yes, that’s sarcasm.

<font color="#3366ff" size="4">So, tomorrow begins the start of the new schedule in the house. More time for job hunting, house hunting and project work. The Monkey starts school and J will be doing whatever he plans on doing during the day. I've got  an exercise plan to work on, a diet plan to map out and a budgeting plan to sort through. Keep those thoughts good and coming...I've a feeling I'm gonna need a strength boost to keep it going, ya know?</font>
Ask me 3 questions, no more no less. Ask me anything you want. Then go to your journal, copy and paste this allowing your friends (including myself) to ask you anything, if you so wish.

I have millions of projects. Literally...ok, a hundred or so. I've been working on going through them for months and for a few of them, years. I've recently made a dent in one of the most important projects, B's educational projects. You see, I've been hearing for years how the teachers can't seem to get him to learn anything, but yet he manages to learn stuff. They can't get him to complete assignments, but he gets the work done. They've done some stupid things and they've done some smart things. I am just tired of the rollercoaster education my poor kid is getting. They change things that work and stick with the stuff that doesn't work, believing that sooner or later he'll do what they want him to do. My frustration levels are a little high on this. 

So I started to teach my son, at home. There are days where I could care less if he finished the work, just that he does his best. I don't agree with the constant changing tactics when my son hits a roadblock. For all their intelligence, I don't think they realize the basic concept of what Aspberger's Disorder is. The only way they will EVER get my son to learn, work or DO anything is to keep him in a constant routine! Yes, he's capable of learning new things, but not if you are mixing up when or by whom he is being taught! CONSTANT routine, is anyone else confused?

Anyway, this afternoon I started to get him ready for the week before school. I'm hoping we're going to at least get him a competent teacher, the worst kind to have is either a first year teacher or a last year teacher...B had a 'last year' teacher in 3rd grade. 4th grade should be different. He/She will need to be strong because his schedule and routine is already going to be new because of his cello lessons. Hopefully, we can pull this off and the teacher will be willing to work with us. I don't think either B or I can handle another lackluster teacher.

Well, that would have to be .....my first spanking....no wait, it was just before that....ah, yes.

I was around 5 years old and I was outside trying to make a snowman. I was crying because my brother and sister didn't want to help me, they wanted to watch TV, so they left me outside by myself to build this snowman. So, with my frozen snot and crusted lashes, I rolled the body of the snowman. I was rolling and rolling and rolling and so on. It was bigger than me before I realized that I was very close to the open pit my father and his friends dug to repair our septic tank. I knew I wasn't allowed to be near it so I tried to turn my really big snowman away, he didn't move. So I got on the other side of him and tried to push. I tried, I was very small when I was 5. 

He didn't like being pushed because he didn't move. I pushed so hard, I cried some more. I decided that I needed my brother for this, so I was going to go get him. For some reason my snowman wouldn't let go of me. I was very scared and angry with him. Then I noticed the problem. 

My mittens got stuck to the snowman. I panicked and started to pull. The snowman must have thought I wanted a hug, because it rolled towards me. This couldn't end well. He was too big to hug me. I knew this from many a visit from my Aunt who would always insist that I be squished between her breasts. I assured her I could not breath each time but she always said, "Nonsense, give me a squeeze." I don't think she understood that she was the one squeezing.

Anyway, back to my overly-amorous snowman. Remember that precarious pit? I didn't, at least not until my foot slipped over the edge. I tried to explain to the snowman that we were doomed and that hugging could wait. He insisted that we weren't and kept rolling towards me. For one instant in a child's imagination, the snowman became my Aunt. For that one instant, he said, "Nonsense, give me a squeeze." I was very scared now, my snowman was one big breast, no cleavage meant no airhole, you see.

It didn't matter anyway, my other foot went over the edge. I was now dangling from my frosty friend who was a little too keen to jump into the pit for my taste. Also not doing too well for my taste was the lovely smell wafting up from the pit. I would later reference that stench to a movie that would win my heart forever. Bluto would state, "Bad smell!" and I would relive that tragic experience all over again.

Once again, back to the suicidal snowman and my hostage crisis. They say when faced with imminent death your life flashes before your eyes, being 5 I had better things to do. I kicked and screamed. I called for help. Eventually I had to stop though. I needed to try to hold on to something, my hands were starting to slip out of the mittens. If that happened I was about to have the smelliest swimming lesson anyone has ever had.

Did you know you can't reason with a snowman? No matter how hard you try, nothing gets past his ear drums. I think it is called frozen reception or something. Here I was, about to die a horrible, stinky death. Here he was, about to commit homicide and suicide at the same time with great joy. It wasn't fair. How could my brother and sister choose television over helping me? I wouldn't be in this mess if they had just helped me to begin with. So, wouldn't you know it...I was crying again.

I don't know if it was my crying or kicking and screaming but my snowman stopped rolling. I looked up as best I could with amazement and sure enough, he had stopped rolling. He had run out of ground. He was now slipping over the edge. Through some miracle of timing, fate, too much Tom & Jerry, or divine intervention from the PTBs; I managed to roll that dropping snowman under me mid-flight and land on top of him as he landed in the mire below. 

Wonders never cease, I was alive. Yet, here I was about to get a lesson on the various physical states of snow. Falling from the sky, snow is beautiful, light and fluffy. Once upon the ground, it can be manipulated into varios shapes, mostly ball form. Over time, it disappears. These things I already knew from basic observation. What I didn't know what that coming in contact with a warm mass of liquid-type material, snow becomes something else. First, steam. Second, nothing. 

My very large snowman was suddenly on a crash diet. My would-be-assassin turned savior was now disintegrating right under me. I had only one hope. I had to stretch my tiny 3 foot body to its full height, jump to the edge of the pit and hold on until someone came for me. I was about to become my own action hero. The problem here is...I have never passed the monkey bar test. I could never hold on for more than two rungs. I was a goner.

This time, faced with death, I cried and peed my pants. I figured it didn't matter, we were all going to end up in the same place. Once again, I screamed and called for help. At the last possible moment, as mittens started to lose their delicate hold, my true savior arrived. My brother, in only his long johns and slippers, was kneeling at the edge pulling with all of his might. I was covered in feces and snow. He didn't let it bother him too much, he kept right on pulling. 

So my first memory was quite the adventure. Isn't it a wonder why my imagination is so lively? Of course not, my first snowman tried to kill me. Wait to you hear about the time I met the Easter Bunny.

I've been trying to think through the murk that is my current state of mind lately and I haven't gotten very far. Then I think of what is going on in my son's life and I can jump from point A to point B pretty damn fast. I'm infuriated with his teacher lately. I'm just so fed up with the way she's been treating him and how she's been behaving when he ignores her. He's lost all respect for her because he can tell she's given up on him. She barely talks to him now because he frustrates her so quickly. She doesn't teach him anything anymore, I end up having to do all that when he gets home. 

There are a few things that I've been noticing and I'm just so fed up with it all. This No Child Left Behind Act was supposed to be a good thing, ya know? Now it is just an excuse for them to fast track as many kids as possible through the curriculum without checking to see if they actually absorbed anything. Now my son has to go to Summer School to make sure that he meets the requirments for the next grade, which means I have to spend the entire month of July teaching my son how to read, write and perform math problems like a normal soon-to-be-fourth grader. Unfortunately, B is not a normal kid. Unless I've been reading all of the reports wrong or something, he's been officially diagnosed with Aspberger's Syndrome/Disease (they change the last part all the time so I'm not sure which he has, I'll have to put that on my list of questions for the interrogation). So, that means he can't be taught like normal kids or that he thinks like normal children do. 

At this point, I'm going to be requesting either a new curriculum or a permanent assistant for my son. His main problem is focusing, being able to concentrate at one task at a time is seriously difficult for him. Most of the work that he does usually has to be monitored so that he will actually do it. She's getting upset about having to constantly tell him to get back to work. Um, did she forget? I don't understand how she is going to get aggravated by having to tell a student to get back to work who is noted as having a focusing problem and that he requires someone to tell him to GET BACK TO WORK???!!! 

~deep breath~

Ok, I have a school meeting coming up on the 10th. I've got my handy-dandy notebook and I'm going to make a teacher cry. My mantra for that day? "I will not slap the teacher, I will not slap the teacher, I will not slap the teacher....."

Wish me luck.

<lj-template name="qotd" id="380"></lj-template> <font color="#0000ff" size="4">My son. He was having what we call a bad day. He was having trouble expressing himself and when I tried to help he told me shut up and made a slightly feral growl. I deserved a HUGE Mommy of the year award for not knocking him for it. I knew it was just his own frustration but damn I had to take a time out that day.</font>

<lj-template name="qotd" id="316"></lj-template><font color="#3366ff" size="3"> I'm told I am pretty so many times, I'm beginning to doubt the veracity of the compliment. That's not what bothers me. What bothers me about receiving this compliment is that it comes whenever I wear something 'girlish'. You know, a skirt and some fairly decent jewelry. They say it with such surprise that irks the hell out of me. Apparently I'm a walking wreck every other time they see me.</font>

My name is Rhoda. Not Rhonda, there is no 'n' in my name. I have started to ignore people who keep thinking that I don't know my own name. I've actually been asked if I was sure that my name is Rhoda or not.

I was not named after Mary Tyler Moore's roommate or whatever. The show was a bit before my time, at least before my cognitive memory so don't ask me if I remember it. I was named after my mother and my aunt, and guess what...they weren't named after the show's characters either. Surprisingly enough the name Rhoda has been around a bit before television. 

Online I go by Rho. It just simplifies things. I hate having to explain this to people who can't understand the level of frustration through a simple font.

You Are 71% Sexy
Your Sex Appeal Is: Extremely High You're very sexy. You just have that certain something that takes over a room. You know how to attract, entice, and keep whoever you want. You are truly appealing.
How Much Sex Appeal Do You Have?

People Definitely Like You
You are very well liked, and many people admire you. You are friendly, well mannered, and fun to be around. Of course, you're not perfect... but that's okay. Your friends are usually willing to accept you for who you are! What People Don't Like About You: People don't like that you forget them easily. No one wants to be friends with someone who doesn't remember their name! People don't like that you put others down and like to gossip. They are worried that you also gossip about them! What People Like About You: People like that you take responsibility for your actions and admit your mistakes. They appreciate your maturity. People like that you are genuine and real. They can count on you to be yourself. People like your self deprecating sense of humor and that you don't take yourself too seriously.
Do People Like You?

What Rhoda Means
You are wild, crazy, and a huge rebel. You're always up to something. You have a ton of energy, and most people can't handle you. You're very intense. You definitely are a handful, and you're likely to get in trouble. But your kind of trouble is a lot of fun. You are truly an original person. You have amazing ideas, and the power to carry them out. Success comes rather easily for you... especially in business and academia. Some people find you to be selfish and a bit overbearing. You're a strong person. You are well rounded, with a complete perspective on life. You are solid and dependable. You are loyal, and people can count on you. At times, you can be a bit too serious. You tend to put too much pressure on yourself. You are balanced, orderly, and organized. You like your ducks in a row. You are powerful and competent, especially in the workplace. People can see you as stubborn and headstrong. You definitely have a dominant personality. You are usually the best at everything ... you strive for perfection. You are confident, authoritative, and aggressive. You have the classic "Type A" personality.
What's Your Name's Hidden Meaning?

Alrighty...let's see this week started off great. I got Bradan and Jason registered for some father/son time at the local college. I hope everything works out ok.

Tuesday I had to go get a small bowel xray done to find out what is going on with my intestines lately. That was AWFUL! 2 rather large cups of barium and 2 1/2 hours later, I finally got the x-rays done, which meant I could eat. I was starving to death. Why is it that they can think of changing the smell of the barium so your nose doesn't trigger your gag reflex and they can change the beginning taste of the barium so that you don't spit it out but they can't finish the alterations to remove the damned aftertaste?! I was ok with the coconut smelling stuff, I was ok with the chalky almost milky taste but I nearly lost it with the bile flavored aftertaste. What gives?

It took me most of the day to process anything food wise. Jason took me shopping to help me feel better. I bought pajamas and shirts. I normally don't wear pajamas but I've been mandated to celibacy while I'm still married to J so, no more sleeping nekkid. Anywho, I also noticed that most of my nice white t-shirts have yellow pits. J thinks that this is because of my smoking days and I emitted my nicotine through my sweat glands. It is a plausible theory, I suppose. So, I've washed them to the best of my ability and have given the best ones to Goodwill and threw out the ones who didn't have a hope.

Wednesday, I will hate February 6th for the rest of my life. I had to cleanse myself for the....colonoscopy I had scheduled for Thursday morning. If any of you have ever gone through this, I'm sorry. If you haven't, you will someday and for that I'm also sorry. First 1 1/2 oz of phospho-soda with 4 oz of water....OH MY GODS!!!!!! Why didn't they just say I had to drink salty monkey piss?! I got through it but I have no idea how. They said 'diarrhea should begin soon'. How soon? No one is sure, it's different for different people. Great, so 2 hours later, I'm in my bathroom wondering about the medical ramifications of anus becoming a high-pressure water hose that isn't spitting water.

Sorry, I just realized how graphic that was. Anyway, onward:

Several hours later, I am exhausted and (I think) finally empty enough to go to sleep. I get up in the night a few times but nothing major is coming out. I am not looking forward to Thursday morning's routine. Seeing as I have to get up at 3AM to start it all off.

3:30 AM - I have my second 1 1/2 oz of phospho-soda and 4 oz of water. I barely get it all down. I now have 30 minutes to get 3 8 oz glasses of water down me. Yeah, right.

4AM - I'm not feeling well. I'm bloated from all the damned liquids and my stomach is nervous about all the sloshing going on. I'm sipping water to help get the next set of ugh out of me.

4:05 AM - Not feeling well. Hot, sweaty and very tired. Wait, my mouth is watering. Aw hell......

4:15 AM - Well, that was loads of fun. At least I didn't crap myself while vomiting, that would have just been more work. I'm too tired for this, I'm ready to call the doc and tell him I can't make it...damn, he says that I'll be fine. The colonoscopy is still on. Son of a b****!

5:00 AM - I'm tired, I'm taking a nap. Wake me at 6:30.

6:30AM - Dammit! I just dozed off. Ok, I'm off to take a shower.

6:45AM - That was nasty. Thank goodness for powerful bathroom drains and antibacterial cleansers. ~shiver~

7:15AM - I changed my mind, I don't want to go. I feel fine. I'm sure it is just nothing. I'll be fine, just let me get some sleep. Bastard....I should kick you.

7:35AM - We're here. I'll go in and go to the bathroom. You get to park the car....you better come back for me.

7:45AM - No, I'm not ready. Yes, I'm nervous. ~sigh~ Let's get it over with.

9:00AM - Hmmm? Thanks, I think. What do you mean there wasn't anything in there?! What the heck is causing all my problems then? Yes, I'm glad it's no cancer or anything but dammit, there has to be some kind of explanation!

~sigh~ I'm tired. We had 'lunch' at Perkins (I think). We came home and we crashed until 1. I'm not allowed to drive for the rest of the day and I don't have enough energy to make dinner. So, J got me some money from the ATM and B and I walked over to our favorite restaurant/hangout. The walked helped to clear the demoral cobwebs and it was pretty good exercise.

I'm ready to get the kidlet through his homework so I can fold clothes and veg out on the sofa. I saw some interesting shadows I wanted to stare at earlier.

Hope y'all are having a better week than I am.

<lj-template name="qotd" id="81"></lj-template> For the most part I'm a 5% tipper. Now, if the meal I've eaten is more than, say, $20 I tend to add one percentage point for every $10 after. So a $40 meal would be a 7% tip and so on.

Not that there isn't anything new going on there, huh? I spent this morning doing laundry and dishes and wondering what to make for dinner. I had to make a gynecological appointment due to some feminine issues I appear to be having, nothing traumatic. I sent out a few updating e-mails to my family to say hey and I sent out a hello there e-mail to the company that has been getting me a job for the past 5 months. I got a call back from one of them. It wasn't the family. The company wasn't awarded the contract, therefore I have nothing to look forward to. I was so overwhelmingly depressed by the news, I threw up. Happy F-ing Friday.

If you won $100 this afternoon, what would you do with it?

Hmmmm, I guess because I'm so freaking hungry right now, I'd say go to Red Lobster and enjoy some seafood. Perhaps I would take my 'lovely' husband and my son to Olive Garden or something else equally 'nice'.

stand on my head.
howl at the moon.
bark like a dog.
read until I fall asleep.
sing until I lose my voice.
nap on the patio.
listen to the radio.
paint a picture.
draw a picture.
read with my monkey.
walk around downtown.
stare out the window.
watch tv.
stare at the walls.
sleep.

So, I've been working on a million things lately. I've been trying to stay busy but I'm getting to the point where THAT doesn't even help. I have to hear something from these people. I can't just sit here for much longer.

Well, I have to do the laundry and take a quick shower. I'm taking Bradan to the library for a storytelling event. Woohoo. :|

I don't know how or why I ever was blessed with this boy and I don't know how or why I ever was cursed with his father. They don't really have to remind me that I got one from the other all the time, you know.

Monkey is currently sitting on the floor in the livingroom actually cussing at his video game. Well, not cussing but doing his version of it. He doesn't want to get in trouble after all. He gets frustrated and pounds his fists on his legs and yells furiously at the game. Yeah, he has moments where he is really just Jason's mini-me. 

I'm just so happy that I get to have these moments without anger or pain. I just have the ability to sit back and notice the similarities.

Scientists unearth Superman's 'kryptonite' - Science - MSNBC.com

I have several friends who are absolutely NUTS about comics and this just caught my eye. I also have several friends who believe they are descendants of Superman. I guess this would be an interesting way to tell wouldn't it?

Soooo, I was going to take the kidlet to the park today...couldn't somehow I have no gas in my car. "Sorry, hon. Forget to mention it." Apparently we use my car so we don't use up our own gas...ok, gas is expensive I get that. Don't you think you should have asked first?

Anywho, so....I could take the kidlet for a walk but thrusting that much activity on the kid without prep? Probably not a good idea. He spends so much time in doors, being outside for too long tends to make him uncomfortable. He's scared of bees this year. I have no clue why.

Soo, I make him get dressed. I take him outside and give him his big push car he got for Easter. "What am I supposed to do?" Um, push it around, hon. It's fun. Try it.

I can't believe I had this experience today. Now, does anyone wonder why I have an issue with leaving Bradan with Jason for too long? I had to explain to my son that just because it was a weekend did not mean that we could spend the entire day in our pajamas. I mean, sure you COULD but what about being outside and doing other things children do? He says "But it's outside, I can't go outside by myself. I'm scared to be out there all alone."

Nevermind that there are twenty children running past his bedroom window as he says this to me. Nevermind that the sun is shining and it's glorious and it makes me itch that I'm inside and I'm not out in it. What I don't get is how he's scared to be outside without me. As if I would just send him out there all alone? What the hell is going on when I'm not around? I know Jason wouldn't do that, Jason would love to stay inside until Hell froze over. So this has to be coming from somewhere, right?

But where? School? Daycare? It can't be TV, we haven't had TV in almost a year. I don't understand. I have enforced the standard "don't talk to strangers" rule and "never go off with children you don't know until you've talked to me first", but I haven't given him anything remotely fear worthy. They were just cautionaries because there was a chance of danger, a chance that someone could take him away. Who's changing the chance to a definitive problem? I hate surprises like these. It just feels like I have to start over in the playing outside department.

So, I forced him to play while I sat on the steps and watched. He started to enjoy himself, then a bee flew past his head and we HAD to go inside. At least, we had some outside time.

I forgot to take the camera with me, but it was inside that the fun started. I've been decluttering my apartment for a few months now. It's a slow process but I'm making progress and it feels great. I had a box flattened out on the floor of my living room from one of my decluttering events. He asked me what I was going to do with it. I said I don't know. He asked if he could have it. I said sure.

The car meant nothing to him, folks. This box was the coolest thing he played with ALL day. Go figgure.

My son was diagnosed with Aspberger's Syndrome a little over a year and a half ago. I've been trying to mill around for support and ways to make his learning life go easier ever since. I go through mounds of information everyday in the hopes that something will work for him. 

On another site that I'm a member of, one of the other people with an autistic/aspi child sent this out to the rest of us. It's a quiz to test to see how bad the parents are. We all got a kick out of it but it really showed us how much of us is transmitted down to our children. Check it out.


http://www.rdos.net/eng/Aspie-quiz.php

I don't know where my head has been lately. I've been jumping from one thought to the next alot. I've started a 'plan' to keep myself occupied. This 'plan' is a cleaning, declutttering, and organizing plan. It is designed with two things in mind. 

1. I need to keep busy to keep my mind from wandering too far into the pain.
2. I need to build a routine to help me keep the apartment clean and to get rid off all the excess crap that I won't need once I get the money to move out.

Alright, technically that's three things but I'm keeping it simple here. My mind sometimes wanders into the wrong directions. A joke in my e-mail and I want to call my mom and tell it to her. A question pops up and I want to write her a letter and talk about it. 

I still have to write a letter to my little brother but I don't know what to say. What is there to say? "Sorry mom's dead. How are you holding up?" Yeah, he probably hasn't heard that question a million times in the past month. I hurt so far down inside that I can't even cry anymore. There's a whole there and I can just can't fill it with enough things to make it better.

That's wrong, this whole thing is wrong. My mom can't be dead, can't be, can't be. She's too full of life, she was just getting her freedom back....she's gone. Why?

I don't understand. How? Why? I feel like I just talked to her and now she's gone. I wrote her a letter and I was waiting for her response and now she's not gonna write one back. When I found out that she was sick, I immediately went out and bought a get well card. You want to know what it said?

It was one of those Maxine cards... On the outside it says:

"Sometimes, when life seems hard, I sing a little song."

On the inside: 

"I figure, hey, I'm suffering, so should the people around me! (see if this works for you.)"

The truly brilliant thing about this card is that my mom couldn't carry a tune in a dump truck. EVERY song she sang came out operatic. It was endearing, hilarious and really awful to listen to. 

So, now I have this card and.....I can't even send her the fucking card!

Sunday, February 4, 2007.

I wake up early, not sure why...I hardly ever wake up early on the weekends. 7:08, my cell phone rings. It's my older brother. Great. Gods know that I love talking to him, yeah that's sarcasm. Hopefully my mom is out of the hospital and they are calling to tell me her kidney infection is and everything else was all better now. She was transported to Dothan, AL a couple of days ago to get someone to operate without making things worse. They found out she had ovarian cancer and a growth of some kind on her liver. However, she had a massive infection around her ovary and entwined in her intestines. They had to get rid of the infection before they could do anything else for her. They said she was in ICU but stable and working through an antibiotic regiment. No big deal. Everyone was sounding hopeful and everything was sure to turn out alright. So the call on Sunday morning should have been to tell me that everything worked out and that she was on her way home or to recovery...or something just as happy.

Should have been....

Wasn't....

I mean, come on, this is my life we're talking about. Since when do I have something GOOD going on? You didn't think this was going to end happily did you? If you did, I'm sorry but I don't think you've been paying attention very well.

Here is where the world kind of tilts a little and you're sure there's a punch line. You even tilt your head to the side to match the skewed view you've been given sure that the punchline will be transmitted any moment now. Any moment now. If only you could speak the language of the cosmos, surely you'd get the joke.

But I don't, and I sit with my head tilted to the side with a cramp in my neck and I'm still wondering....any minute now that punchline is gonna come. Just wait one moment.

Nothing.

There is no joke but the one I played on myself. Believing that for just one moment I was dreaming, stuck in a nightmare, trapped in my own little world that sucks me into daydreaming from time to time. No dreams here, not even nightmares, except of the heart of course.

But they're the worst...nightmares of the heart leave scars and residue and permanent pain. They echo off of your memories. Even the stuff where you normally don't think twice about suddenly stops you short. A walk through a store and a simple ball of yarn, "Mom would love that color."

Damn, I almost went one hour without thinking about her. Almost.

FOR MY MOM

You left today for a better place,

one where you wouldn't suffer.

I find it hard to accept it all

with such ease and selflessness.

 

I'll keep your laugh, smiles and love

just so I can give them back

when we meet again.

It may be a while though.

 

You left today for a better place,

save me a seat.

I'll tell you some great stories

I'll even give back your laugh.

Congrats, Mari!!!

This law would NEVER change and would be enforced by your own private army of goons.

Based upon my own life experiences and encouters, I would have to say that everyone below a base IQ level (keeping in mind their age and productivity level) would be given a year to improve said IQ through education and therapy. If by the end of that year, your IQ has not improved or your productivity (or worth as an active member of the society in which you live) you shall be euthanized.

Now it has been pointed out that this may end up removing the service class. I don't think so, I believe the social order would be restructured to allow for the change. If not, this at least begins to address what to do about immigration issues. At least that would lead to the improvement of other classes from other countries.

This leads me to what I mean by level of productivity. A fully functioning memeber of society would have some way of contributing to the society to which they belong. This would, ideally, remove the village idiots. Also, to note, elderly and comatose people. If your status has shown no improvement within a year then you will be euthanized. Newly comatose patients, from accidents or natural causes, should be given a standard month to show signs of improvement. If none presents itself, the insurance company shall cancel it's policy and the family members will be responsible for all medical bills after that month. This gives them the option to continue to pay or euthanize the patient.

Yes, you'll grieve. However, you will be forced to weigh this decision carefully, within a year they will be euthanized anyway. I'd try to view the whole process from this prospective:
             If it is the memories of that person that you cling to, there is no reason for you to keep the body alive. The memories will stay with you. If it is the personality of the person you cling, realize this - a person waking from a coma rarely returns back to the way they were before the coma, it is a traumatic experience to 'wake up' and try to return to 'normal' when you are missing a chunk of your life and everyone else around you has changed. After keeping this in mind, think of your family pet. If the poor creature has suffered an injury or disease that removes their mobility, the vet bills to tend to the animal become enormous, and they just aren't their old self anymore - would you spare your family the pain of their slow loss or allow the poor thing to be put down so that you can lay them to rest and let your family have a chance to say goodbye and time to heal. Let's face it, you'll probably get a new pet by the end of the year anyway.

Now I'm not suggesting that a person would be easy to replace. But by not allowing yourself the chance to heal or move on you are giving this person, this body that holds only memories, a higher value than over your own life. You are allowing them selfish control over your life, does that fit the personality of the body with all those memories locked inside?

Then there's the will to live perspective. I've heard time and time again that a person "couldn't live without" so and so. I don't believe this for one minute. How did you survive up to the point of meeting this all important person? Have you known them since your exit from the womb? grade school? high school? college? Did you actually not exist until you met this person? Had you possibly never interacted with another person before them? And you honestly believe that you will cease to do so now that they are dead?

The very nature of a human life is to grow and experience life. Every interaction you have with someone builds upon who you are and how you grow as a person. This in turn helps to develop how you fit into the society to which you live, it develops your purpose and place in the world. If it in fact is your time to leave this world, whether you know it or not, it rarely has anything to do with what you feel you have left to do but rather with what you haven't done.

Based upon my own experience, when faced with imminent death most people rarely think of what they have done with their life but rather of all the things they hadn't done up to their death. Then there is a brief acknowledgement of what they regret having said or done during their life that they feel was either out of line or deplorable.

In the end, my point is simple. Don't be stupid, live life for yourself and those that you love but don't be consumed by what you believe other people want of you. Ask questions and find out, be honest and talk openly. In the end, only you can better yourself and only you can carry the memories that you cherish, don't make others suffer because you choose to be selfish. Death in itself is selfish, it doesn't need any help.
